issue.title: Image without scaling, unless needed?

comment.body:
Generally speaking, translating resolution (pixels) to physical size (points) does not make sense, as the conversion logic depends on the DPI and is related to final visual fidelity. 

You can make certain assumptions yourself. In the PDF world, 1 inch = 72 points. Then you can choose the DPI value - usually around 300 for printed documents. QuestPDF uses 288 by default (4 * 72 = 288) when scaling down images. 

Then, calculating physical size is easy. Example for an image of width 1024px: `1024 / 288 * 72 = 256pt`

issue.title: Image without scaling, unless needed?
'\t' character in string throws a DocumentDrawingException with Arial font.

comment.body:
Indeed, the support in OpenXML is trivial as the rendering process is entirely handled by the Word processor.

The difficulty here is that the tab glyph is not a visual character but a particular corner case that needs to be handled explicitly in the text rendering code. It can be as simple as inserting an empty space, whose size is dependent on the configured tab size and the total horizontal size of all text runs before the tab in the current line. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tab_key

But my experience says that nothing related to text rendering is simple 🤣

So the only question is, how many users require this feature and at what level?

issue.title: '\t' character in string throws a DocumentDrawingException with Arial font.

comment.body:
@MarcinZiabek Thank you for your detailed response! Absolutely agree with everything you wrote

> ignore this character (I believe this is done by most of the libraries)

If we're not just talking about `PDF`, I've seen libraries (like `DocX`) that support the `\t` glyph. But the problem is that `OpenXML`, unlike `PDF`, knows how to handle `\t` by default with a special element called `tab`

> In such a case, QuestPDF should somehow handle the \t character to prevent runtime errors

We can look at `OpenXML` and do something like this: http://officeopenxml.com/WPtab.php. I mean `\t` glyph should be treated as a separate element within `TextBlock`

issue.title: Code quality improvement in TextStyleManager
issue.body:
### Changes
- **Added `GetValue` and `SetValue` methods to `TextStyle` to get property value using `TextStyleProperty`**

- **Added `StylesApplyingOptions` record to store `OverrideStyle`, `OverrideFontFamily` and `AllowFallback` properties**
Before
![image](https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/assets/55300023/8c1c3ca6-4dda-4f9f-9f36-5aeefebdf4b0)
After
![image](https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/assets/55300023/16a6bb86-b9d8-4df7-bbd6-4c1872c4d97d)

- **Simplified `MutateStyle` method**
Before
![image](https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/assets/55300023/bc8299c1-5a09-47d8-8c1e-a5fb58193fc8)
After
![image](https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/assets/55300023/a46ee9b0-50bd-4d99-b458-b3f6727ff62a)

- **Simplified `ApplyStyleProperties` method**
After
![image](https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/assets/55300023/dff4831c-4952-4a0e-90e4-88172f52923b)
Before
![image](https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/assets/55300023/8008090b-7c7e-4ae5-9e6b-d6d23e96d695)

comment.body:
Thank you so much for investigating the code and providing this improvement. I highly appreciate your help.

This area of the library is quite interesting. At the beginning of the development process, the idea of an immutable TextStyle object was introduced. Consequently, according to functional programming, performing any change instantiates a new object. In specific FluentAPI chains, this may result in multiple TextStyle objects per Text element. As a result, it is very taxing on the garbage collector.

This code was designed to mitigate the creation of new TextStyle instances by tracking the type of change and looking for potentially already existing class instances. To make the code even faster, multi-level caches were introduced.

Still, we need to be careful. Introducing reflection may significantly reduce performance (especially in multi-threaded scenarios) by increasing the GC load. Making proper tests may help with decision-making.

issue.title: '\t' character in string throws a DocumentDrawingException with Arial font.

comment.body:
Thank you so much for investigating this issue! I highly appreciate your help. 

I believe that the problem could be more subtle than we think. Indeed, the font may define the tab `\t` codepoint but at the same time may not contain its visual representation - and therefore cause the error. At the same time, SkiaSharp has limited text rendering capabilities. Maybe more sophisticated features are on the client side, for example: shaping, Unicode standard and special characters (such as new-line `\n` and tab `\t`) support.

In such a case, QuestPDF should somehow handle the `\t` character to prevent runtime errors. There are a couple of potential strategies:
1) ignore this character (I believe this is done by most of the libraries),
2) replace it with an arbitrary number of spaces,
3) replace it with an empty space of specific size,
4) implement proper support.

I believe that options 2) and 3) are relatively close to the desired behavior, especially when the '\t' character is at the very beginning of the line. While option 1) is the most straightforward.

In the future, this problem may be solved entirely as part of the https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/discussions/622 effort. So even temporary improvements could be beneficial.

What do you think?

issue.title: Exception related to skiaSharp-related library
issue.body:
Hi, I'm facing an issue with missing dependency I think. I'm running my api in docker-compose in microservices architecure and when trying to generate pdf, getting this error: 

`Cannot create the PDF document using the SkiaSharp-related library. This exception usually means that, on your operating system where you run the application, SkiaSharp-related requires installing additional dependencies. Such dependencies are available as additional nuget packages, for example *.NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies. Some operating systems may require installing multiple nugets, e.g. MacOS may need both *.NativeAssets.macOS.NoDependencies and *.NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies.Please refer to the SkiaSharp-related documentation for more details. Also, please consult the inner exception that has been originally thrown by the dependency library.`

And deeper in stack trace:

`System.DllNotFoundException: Unable to load shared library 'libSkiaSharp' or one of its dependencies.`
`libfontconfig.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory /usr/share/dotnet/shared/Microsoft.NETCore.App/7.0.12/libSkiaSharp.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

I've tried to install both libraries, NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies and NativeAssets.Linux, either solo and both in one time. Also I was searching for solution, and found a few topics, so I've also tried to add this to dockerfile:

`RUN apt-get update`
`RUN apt-get install -y libfreetype6`
`RUN apt-get install -y libfontconfig1`
`RUN apk update \`
`    && apk --no-cache add icu-libs fontconfig ttf-dejavu`

In the end, none of these solutions helped me, after looking to docker files of my service, I see that there is libSkiaSharp.so in app/bin/Debug/net7.0/runtimes/linux-arm/native/libSkiaSharp.so and there is not in here: /usr/share/dotnet/shared/Microsoft.NETCore.App/7.0.12/libSkiaSharp.so

I'll be grateful for any help, I would like to use your library, after testing almost every pdf generator I'm not seeing any other option, QuestPDF is honestly the best. 

Thank you

comment.body:
I wonder why the exception says `SkiaSharp-related` (which is a default, fallback value)

Technically, there already is [logic that should detect if the exception is about SkiaSharp or HarfbuzzSharp](https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/blob/main/Source/QuestPDF/Drawing/Exceptions/InitializationException.cs), and then provide a more detailed message. The logic is quite simple, just checking if a given keyword is present in the exception message text.

`libSkiaSharp` corresponds to SkiaSharp, while `libHarfBuzzSharp` to HarfBuzzSharp. 

Also, it is unexpected that the exception was saying `libSkiaSharp` but you needed to install `HarfBuzzSharp.NativeAssets.Linux` to resolve the issue.

issue.title: Docs are stuck in 1990's - need AWS or Azure example
issue.body:
The QuestPDF docs and examples offer no working guidance on how to use QuestPDF in the cloud. The docs and examples all seem to assume we are writing desktop applications that run on Windows and read and write to the local filesystem. 

StackOverflow, GitHub, and Reddit are full of questions from devs trying to figure out how to get QuestPDF's SkiSharp (and HarfBuzzSharp?) dependencies working in AWS and Azure. At this point I'm personally days into trying to get something that is nothing more than a hello world QuestPDF application to run in Azure, and it's still not rendering in the cloud even though it runs on both Windows and OSX.

Azure and AWS stopped being "new" more than ten years ago. Azure and AWS have .NET devs running our .NET code on Linux. QuestPDF treats cross-platform generally and Linux in particular as not worthy of documenting. This is a HUGE waste of your potential customer's time. 

If QuestPDF is to be a commercial product, please show us it is a commercial-quality product by providing an example that runs in the cloud in Azure or AWS. Telling your customers to "go read the (nonexistent or inadequate) SkiSharp docs" is not an answer. This is a QuestPDF problem. 

At present, I have things to the point where I'm getting the following exception, but please don't just add an answer here in this thread on this particular issue. Be kind to your potential customers. Provide an actual working example so no other devs have to waste their time chasing down undocumented platform dependencies like I've been doing, and like all the other similarly frustrated devs I'm "met" through their StackOverflow, GitHub, and Reddit threads have had to deal with.

```
QuestPDF.Drawing.Exceptions.InitializationException: Cannot create the PDF document using the SkiaSharp-related library. This exception usually means that, on your operating system where you run the application, SkiaSharp-related requires installing additional dependencies. Such dependencies are available as additional nuget packages, for example *.NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies. Some operating systems may require installing multiple nugets, e.g. MacOS may need both *.NativeAssets.macOS.NoDependencies and *.NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies.Please refer to the SkiaSharp-related documentation for more details. Also, please consult the inner exception that has been originally thrown by the dependency library.
```

Again, to be clear, please add a working example that runs in either Azure or AWS, including all the required Linux dependencies.

comment.body:
First, I would like to thank everybody for participating in this conversation. I highly appreciate your feedback and am sorry for replying with a delay.

---

The library already contains code recognising potential problems with native SkiaSharp and HarfbuzzSharp dependencies. The existing implementation tries to suggest what nuget packages could be missing: https://github.com/QuestPDF/QuestPDF/blob/main/Source/QuestPDF/Drawing/Exceptions/InitializationException.cs

However, after analysis, I have found a couple of corner cases that may prevent this implementation from working correctly. The code above currently handles exceptions during PDF / XPS file generation. But the System.DllNotFoundException is thrown as soon as the runtime code touches SkiaSharp/HarfbuzzSharp modules, potentially way before attempting PDF generation. For example, when generating images or registering custom fonts.

At this moment, I am experimenting with an improvement that should better recognize which dependency causes problems and suggest what nuget should be installed to run the code in a given runtime. Hopefully, this will improve the overall experience. I will publish an alpha release shortly.

Additionally, the `SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies` nuget provides should provide all necessary dependencies without the need to alter docker image content. I will make sure to include this detail in the exception message. 

If you have any suggestions or observations, please feel free to share.

---

@yoDon I am sorry for your poor experience. Without a doubt, QuestPDF is on the transition path from a hobby project to a stable, professional product. I am doing my best to prioritize certain efforts and narrow the gap possibly fast.

I would like to emphasize that updating dependencies is different between libraries and projects. At this moment, I think that the library should use possibly the oldest, most commonly used and future-versions compatible dependencies. This reduces the risk of a dependency hell, while moving the security responsibilities to its users. I am usually introducing certain delay before updating to the latest SkiaSharp version. Of course, every strategy has pros and cons.
